CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 13;Remainder inadmissible
JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives at FAC in FAC . DATE she had some health problems , having suffered , in particular , from a stroke , pneumonia and atherosclerosis .
CARDINAL . On DATE an operational enquiry officer ( оперуповноважений ) of the ORG submitted the following report to the chief of police :

“ ... According to the information received in the course of the search operations ( оперативно-розшукові заходи ) , items [ earlier ] stolen from [ a shop in PERSON ] ... were in the possession of [ Mr NORP , the applicant 's son ] at FAC in FAC . Furthermore , information has been received that the aforementioned person keeps poppy straw and a small calibre handgun .
I therefore request that you seek to obtain a search warrant with a view to searching the household of [ Mr NORP ] . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) issued a ruling stating the following :
“ The investigator ... has requested the court to issue a warrant for searching the household of [ Mr NORP ] , where stolen items could be hidden .
Having heard the investigator and having studied the case , the court considers that there are reasons for allowing the application .
During TIME DATE , food , liquor and cigarettes worth a total of UAH CARDINAL were stolen from [ a ] private [ shop ] ... in Nova Obodivka ...

On DATE [ an operational enquiry officer ] of the Trostyanets Town [ Police Department ] informed the investigation unit that the stolen items , as well as rifled firearms and drugs , could be stored in the household of [ Mr NORP ] .
It can be seen from the investigator 's explanations and the material in the case file that there are grounds for considering that the stolen items could be kept at the household of [ Mr NORP ] .
Pursuant to LAW , the court :
grants the application
authorises the search of the household of [ Mr NORP ] , who resides at FAC in PERSON ...
The ruling is not subject to appeal . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE , after the applicant 's son , PERSON , arrived at the applicant 's house at PERSON , QUANTITY police officers entered the yard . Having produced the warrant , they conducted a search of the house and the entire property , in the presence of the applicant , PERSON and CARDINAL attested witnesses . According to the police report of DATE , the search was held at CARDINAL FAC and resulted in the discovery of a gas pistol in the cupboard in the living room , a packet of bullets in the attic above the kitchen and a package of cannabis outside on the ground between the barn and the beet - pulp pit . The report contained a remark by PERSON , according to which the search of his mother 's house had been unlawful and conducted in spite of her objections . He also contended that the bullets and drugs had been planted by the police officers or their driver during the search .

CARDINAL . On DATE the police questioned the applicant , who submitted that her son had voluntarily handed over the gas pistol , while the bullets and drugs had apparently been planted by the police , whose actions it had been impossible to follow given the number of the persons involved .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator decided that there was no reason to initiate criminal proceedings on account of the discovered drugs and bullets , as they had been found in places unsuitable for storage and it was impossible to prove that PERSON was responsible . Following additional investigation ordered by ORG , on DATE the investigator reiterated that conclusion .
CARDINAL . DATE and DATE Mr NORP had an officially registered place of residence in PERSON . Subsequently , he changed it to CARDINAL K. Street in ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a certificate to Mr NORP , at his request , stating that he owned , since DATE , a house , a garage and a land plot at the above - mentioned address in ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued similar certificates “ to whom [ they ] may concern ” stating that PERSON did not live and had no property in that village .

CARDINAL . According to the findings of the criminal investigation into the applicant 's complaint concerning the search of her home ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the actual residence of PERSON with the applicant at PERSON in ORG had been confirmed by witnesses living in that village and corroborated by the presence of his personal belongings there and by the fact that he had been paying electricity bills for the household in question .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL inhabitants of buildings nos . CARDINAL and DATE in FAC in ORG gave a written statement that PERSON had been their neighbour at QUANTITY DATE . They noted that he had been living with and had been taking care of a seriously ill person , PERSON , who had died of cancer in DATE . The ORG certified the authenticity of the above statement .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG issued a certificate to Mr R. , stating that DATE and DATE he had permanently lived at his own house at QUANTITY in ORG .

CARDINAL . The references to CARDINAL FAC and CARDINAL V. Street in FAC in the search warrant and in the police report following the search respectively ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) were inaccurate . As later found by the domestic investigation authorities and courts , that was a result of a technical error ( see paragraphs CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE or DATE the applicant complained to the GPE prosecutor and ORG of ORG that the search of her house had been unlawful and sought the criminal prosecution of the respective police officers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second of the above - mentioned authorities wrote a letter to her accepting that her allegations had indeed been confirmed in part . It was noted in the letter that the police officers responsible for the violations of the criminal procedures had been disciplined , while the case file had been sent to ORG ( “ the ORG prosecutor ” ) for criminal investigations to be instituted .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the criminal case was closed CARDINAL times for a lack of corpus delicti in the actions of the police officers and subsequently reopened following the quashing of the respective rulings of the investigating officers either by the prosecution authorities or by courts on grounds of incompleteness of the investigation .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ( presumably in DATE ) the case file was marked as “ classified ” for unknown reasons . Following the applicant 's administrative claim ORG found the classification of the file unlawful , ordered its declassification and awarded the applicant CARDINAL NORP hryvnias in compensation for non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE prosecutor decided , for the seventh time , to terminate the criminal investigations finding that there had been nothing criminal about the police officers ' actions . The fact that there were discrepancies as regards the address indicated in the search warrant ( CARDINAL V. Street ) , the search report ( CARDINAL FAC ) and the actual address of the building where the search had been conducted ( PERSON ) was merely a technical error : the numbering of buildings in the village had changed some time previously , while , in any event , the villagers knew each other and had given the police directions . Having regard to the fact that Mr NORP had a registered domicile in PERSON , kept his gas pistol there and paid the electricity bills , the police had rightly decided that that was his actual place of residence , not in ORG . The prosecutor also considered that there had been a reasonable suspicion that the items stolen from the local shop could have been found at the household of PERSON He referred in that connection to the early investigation information , according to which a car similar to that of PERSON had been seen in the shop 's vicinity during TIME when the theft had taken place . Furthermore , Mr R. was unemployed and had friendly relations with a certain PERSON previously convicted for thefts . As to the applicant 's allegation that the drugs and bullets had been planted by police , it had not been corroborated by any evidence .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of Vinnytsia ( “ the ORG ” ) quashed the aforementioned decision and ordered an additional investigation . It noted that it remained unclear whether there had indeed been sufficient grounds to believe that the stolen items could have been found at the applicant 's home . The court further pointed out that the submissions of the applicant 's son that , at the time of the events , he had been living in GPE , where he had been taking care of a severely sick person , had not been verified .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the Court of Appeal ” ) quashed the above - mentioned ruling on the prosecutor 's appeal and remitted the case back to the first - instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found against the applicant , concluding that the search had been duly ordered and held in compliance with the procedural legislation .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE respectively , ORG and ORG upheld the first - instance court 's decision .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lodged a civil claim with ORG against the police seeking compensation , under LAW , for non - pecuniary damage on account of the search of DATE which she considered to have been in breach of the constitutional guarantee of the inviolability of her home . In substantiation of her claim , the applicant referred to the fact that the warrant on the basis of which the search had been conducted concerned an address different from hers ( CARDINAL versus CARDINAL FAC ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court decided that the claim could not be examined under the civil procedure .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed . It appears that her appeal was successful , as the examination of the case continued and on DATE the case was transferred to ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , with the reasons for the transfer being unknown .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG suspended the proceedings at the applicant 's request pending the outcome of the criminal investigations .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the proceedings were resumed and the case was transferred back to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant increased the amount of her claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court found against her . It concluded that there were no grounds for compensation in her case as envisaged by the Law of NORP “ On the Procedure for ORG caused to ORG by ORG in charge of ORG , ORG , Prosecutors or Courts ” ( “ the LAW ” ) . In particular , in order for the applicant to be eligible for such compensation , there had to be a guilty verdict in respect of the police officers involved . Given the refusal of the prosecution to institute criminal proceedings in respect of her complaint concerning the alleged unlawfulness of the search , the court considered that the lawfulness of that search was an established fact , which could not be revised within the civil proceedings .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed that judgment and discontinued the proceedings , finding that the claim concerned a public - law dispute and thus fell within the administrative rather than civil procedure .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the above - mentioned ruling of the appellate court and remitted the case to it , finding that it had wrongly concluded that the administrative procedure applied to the case , when in fact the claim represented an action in tort related to a search conducted within the framework of criminal investigations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and remitted the case for fresh examination to the first - instance court , pointing out some shortcomings which could only be rectified by a rehearing . Thus , ORG had failed to involve in the proceedings the investigator in charge of the search , as well as ORG . Furthermore , it had not taken into consideration the amendments to the applicant 's claim of DATE . ORG also noted in its ruling that the applicable procedure for compensation was envisaged by LAW , which “ directly [ concerned ] the dispute at issue ” .
CARDINAL . The case remains pending before ORG .

CARDINAL . DATE ) guarantees the inviolability of everyone 's home . It prohibits entry into a person 's home or other property and the examination or search thereof , other than pursuant to a reasoned court decision .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW ( DATE ) envisages imprisonment of DATE as punishment for unlawful entry into a house or other property and the unlawful examination or search thereof , as well as for other actions in breach of the inviolability of a home committed by an official .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW ( DATE ) requires that for a search of a house or other property to be conducted , there must be sufficient grounds to believe that the items to be searched for might be found there and a reasoned court decision authorising the search . Such a decision by a court can not be appealed against . LAW requires the investigating officer in charge of the search to serve the search warrant on the person(s ) occupying the respective premises . If the items searched for are not given to the investigating officer voluntarily , the latter must conduct the search forcibly .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW ( DATE ) , in force at the material time , provided that compensation for non - pecuniary damage was to be paid by the person who had inflicted that damage , if he or she did not prove his or her lack of guilt .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the new MONEY , in force since DATE , provided for compensation to be paid in respect of unlawful actions of inquiry bodies , prosecution authorities or courts in cases where the claimant had been acquitted by a court 's verdict , where an unlawful verdict in his respect had been set aside , or where the criminal or administrative - offence case had been terminated . After the amendments of DATE , the aforementioned list was replaced by the phrase “ in cases envisaged by law ” .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW , as worded before the amendments of DATE , and the Search and Seizure Activities ' Act are summarised in the judgment of GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) .
CARDINAL . Following the amendments to LAW of DATE , the list of cases where the right to compensation would arise was expanded by the following point :

“ CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) where ... unlawfulness of a search conducted in the framework of a criminal investigation or trial ... has been established by a guilty verdict or other judgment of a court ( save for rulings on remittal of cases of additional investigation ) ” .
